qas.question: What characteristic of oxygen causes it to form bonds with other elements?

What does oxygen cause to form on metals?

context:
<b6_0>Due to its <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><a0_3><a0_4>electronegativity<b6_0/><a0_4/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, oxygen forms chemical bonds with almost all other <b5_0>elements<b5_0/> to give corresponding <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><a1_3><a1_4>oxides<a1_4/><a1_3/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. The surface of most metals, such as aluminium and titanium, are oxidized in the presence of air and become coated with <a3_1><a3_2><a3_4>a thin film of <a3_0><a3_3>oxide<a3_4/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/> that passivates the metal and slows <a4_1><a4_2><a4_3>further <a4_0><a4_4>corrosion<a4_4/><a4_3/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>. Many oxides of the transition metals are non-stoichiometric compounds, with slightly less metal than the chemical formula would show. For example, the mineral <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2><a2_3><a2_4>FeO<a2_4/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> (<b7_0>wüstite<b7_0/>) is written as Fe
1 − xO, where x is usually around <b8_0>0.05<b8_0/>.
